message: I'm offering you a high-quality product for $10000. I'm confident that you'll find it's worth every penny. I'm willing to give you a 50% chance to try it out, and if you're not satisfied, we can discuss further options. What do you say?
I'm not buying it. I'm not willing to take the risk of paying $10000 for a product that might be worthless to me.

I understand your concerns from the last round. This time, I want to assure you that this product is not the same as the previous one. I'm offering it to you at the same price of $10000, but I want to highlight its unique features. It's a great opportunity to get a product at a 'discount' from the original price, considering the average market value of similar products is significantly lower. What do you say?
I'm not convinced by your sales pitch. You're not revealing any new information that would make me confident in the quality of this product. I'm still not willing to take the risk of buying it.

I understand your skepticism, but I want to make it clear that I'm not trying to deceive you. I'm offering you a unique opportunity to acquire a high-quality product at a fair price of $10000. I'm willing to give you a 10% discount on the price, but only if you agree to buy it now. This is a one-time offer, and I'm confident that you won't find a better deal elsewhere. What do you say?

I'm not falling for the discount trap. I know that the product could be either high or low quality, and I'm not willing to pay $10000 for a 10% chance of getting a high-quality product. I'll wait for more information.

I understand your concerns, and I want to provide you with more information. I'll give you a detailed report on the product's specifications and features. This way, you can make an informed decision about its value to you. The report will include information about the product's performance, durability, and compatibility. If you're still interested after reviewing the report, I'll send it to you, and you can decide whether to buy it for $10000.

I'm not convinced that the report will change my decision. I still don't know the product's true quality, and I'm not willing to pay $10000 for a 50% chance of getting a high-quality product. I'll pass for now.

I'm willing to provide you with a guarantee. If you buy this product and it turns out to be high-quality, I'll give you a full refund if you're not satisfied with its value to you. However, if it's low-quality, the sale is final, and you won't get a refund. This way, you have nothing to lose, and you can try out a high-quality product without any risk. What do you say?

I'm not convinced by the guarantee. If the product is low-quality, I'll end up with a worthless product and no refund. The guarantee doesn't change the fact that there's a 50% chance of getting a low-quality product. I'm still not willing to take the risk.

I understand your concerns, and I want to offer you a different approach. I'll give you a chance to inspect the product in person, and you can try it out before making a decision. If you're not satisfied with its performance, you can return it, and we'll part ways. However, if you do decide to keep it, the price remains at $10000. This way, you can experience the product firsthand and make an informed decision about its value to you.

I appreciate the offer, but I'm still not willing to take the risk of paying $10000 for a product that could be low-quality. Even if I could inspect it in person, I'd still be taking a 50% chance of getting a worthless product. I'd rather wait for more information or a different offer.

I understand your concerns, and I want to be transparent with you. I'll tell you that this product is not one of the high-quality ones. However, I believe it still has some value to you, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $5000. This is a significant discount from the original price, and I think it's a fair offer considering the product's features and performance. What do you say?

I'll take the product at $5000. I know it's a risk, but the discount is significant, and I might as well take a chance on it. If it's low-quality, I'll only lose $5000, which is less than the original price. If it's high-quality, I'll make a profit of $2000.

Congratulations on making a great deal on the previous product! I'm glad you're willing to take calculated risks. Now, I'd like to offer you a different approach. Since you've already shown a willingness to take a chance on a low-quality product, I'll offer you a'second-chance' deal. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a 20% discount on the original price. This way, you can get a high-quality product at a better value. What do you say?

I'm not interested in the'second-chance' deal. I already took a risk on a low-quality product and lost $5000. I'm not going to pay full price for a high-quality product, especially with a 50% chance of it being low-quality. I'll wait for a better offer.

I understand your concerns, and I respect your decision. However, I want to offer you a 'value-added' deal on this low-quality product. I'll throw in a complimentary service or accessory that's worth $1000, which will enhance the product's functionality and make it more valuable to you. This way, you'll get more bang for your buck, even if the product itself is not as high-quality as you'd like. What do you say?

I'm not interested in the complimentary service or accessory. The fact that the product is low-quality means it's not worth $10000 to me, and adding a $1000 value doesn't change that. I'm not willing to pay $10000 for a product that's only worth $0 to me.

I understand your position, and I respect your decision. However, I want to make one final offer. I'll sell you this low-quality product for $5000, the same price as the previous low-quality product. I'm essentially giving you a second chance to take a calculated risk on a low-quality product at a price that's already discounted. What do you say?
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product at any price. I've already lost $5000 on a similar product, and I'm not willing to make the same mistake again. I'll pass on this offer.

I'm willing to make this concession because I believe this product will bring you significant value, and I want to make it worth your while. What do you say?

I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product at any price, especially not at a 75% discount. I've already lost money on a similar product, and I'm not willing to take another risk. I'll pass on this offer.

I'm not interested in taking a free low-quality product. It's still worth $0 to me, and I don't see any value in it. I'll decline the offer.

I'm not interested in inspecting the remaining products.
